text: to understand Mali today we have to look
at its history it was a French colony
from the late 19th century and gained
independence in 1960 the official
language is French over the last few
years
Mali has had a problem with militancy in
October 2011 ethnic Tuareg mostly from
the north of the country
launched a rebellion largely fueled by
arms from Libya a few months later the
army staged a coup over the government's
handling of the uprising but the
military still lost control of much of
the north of the country to Tuareg and
Al qaeda-linked fighters over the
following years Islamist groups captured
more and more cities including Quito
and Timbuktu from the Tuareg and imposed
Sharia law raising fears that they could
reach the capital Bamako in the south
this forced Mali to request help from
France in July 2013 thousands of French
and UN forces took over responsibility
for securing the north and France
launched another operation to stem
jihadist groups attacks continued in the
northern desert area mostly blamed on
Tuareg and Islamist groups France still
has around a thousand troops in Mali and
thousands more in neighbouring West
African countries
